handDesc.p: Halantas. Final M (l27, l32) is usually a simplified ma, but in l37 (twice) it seems to be the later form, a tiny circle with a single sinuous tail. Final T (l27) is a reduced ta with a short vertical tail instead of a headmark.

Other palaeographic observations. Anusvāra is normally above and to the right of the character to which it belongs. Long ī is hardly ever distinct (but occasionally it is, e.g. l8 kīrtteḥ); RM's edition silently reads the ī where appropriate, while my edition shows the short i used instead of long ī as a scribal mistake. Rare initial Au occurs in line 22, though it may have been written as O. RM reads it as Au and there is a faint curved stroke at the top right that, if genuine, distinguishes it from O.

app.note: RM cites the Pr̥thivipallavapaṭṭana grant of Viṣṇuvardhana IV or V as also reading -prabhāvārjjitāśeṣa-, but this may be an oversight. His point is not to corroborate this reading but to indicate that the title is simpler there. It is certain on the basis of several cognate plates that the intended expression was prabhāvāvarjjitāśeṣa-.

app.note: I accept RM's -māṇikka- on the strength of the exact parallel in line 8 of the Zulakallu plates of Vijayāditya I, but in the published estampage the ka seems not to be doubled, and ma does not seem to have an ā attached to it.

Here too, I reconstruct the text on the basis of the Zulakallu plates. In the published estampages, nothing is discernible at the end of line 6 (where RM reads ka), nor at the beginning of line 7 (where he reads nothing before the descender of rjja above). However, I find -kiraṇa-kara- implausible, while there may easily have been a now indistinct sa at the beginning of line 7.
The character ta is quite narrow and may be a correction over something narrower.
The characters na ni are quite narrow and may be a correction over a single character.

app.note: The reading is clear, so this must be some kind of weird typo in RM.
RM's note about the ra being added below the line is wrongly anchored next to the preceding word, timira.

Although the preceding words, in the dative, qualify the donee, I still think this particular compound at least was intended to qualify his grandfather. Note that the specification of residence and affiliation likewise applies to the donee's grandfather, rather than the donee himself, in many related grants.
Here too, I believe this term was meant to apply to the donee's father, not to the donee.

I find RM's emendation unsatisfactory. I am confident that vākyāta is a scribal mistake for vākyārtha or vākyārttha, and the vowel of kyā is quite clear. I am less sure about pramana, but believe that it may be erroneous for pravacana, with one character omitted and either va or ca mistakenly changed to ma. It could also be derived similarly, if less easily, from pracakṣaṇa. Other solutions may well be possible, so I prefer not to show any emendation in the text. Furthermore, the superfluous śa above the characters prabha after this word may be relevant. I show read this as śśa in the previous line, while R apparently ignores it. This could perhaps be a correction intended for this locus, though see also the apparatus to line 25.
I believe this m is not an unwitting mistake but non-standard sandhi involving an epenthetic m.

I accept RM's reading of the received text, which he prints as clear. In the published estampage it is very much unclear; I cannot see a subscript ś at all, though compare line 23 above. RM emends the name to Bhavaśarman, but I prefer not to do so.

The name was read as Raṇḍubaḷḷi for the ARIE report, while RM asserts that it is correctly Reṇḍubaḷḷi. See also the commentary. In my opinion the two dots on either side of the ra-like glyph leave no doubt that it is a long initial Ī. As far as I can see from the printed estampage, the second character could be ndu as well as ṇḍu, while the third is quite indistinct.

I adopt RM's emendation in the name and accept his reading for the last character of line 26, where all I see is a faint descending hook that may be part of a subscript k or a dependent u. RM also prints his ṟka as unclear.
The last two characters of line 28 cannot be made out at all in the printed estampage. RM also prints them as unclear.

RM's emendation is of course perfectly appropriate to the context, but seems to be an unlikely scribal error. I believe the text is garbled from expressions involving Eteṣāṁ catur-avadhi-madhya-varti (cf. the Nemmaḷūru and Dinakādu grants of Vijayāditya I).

This word does not fit the context well and is probably a scribal mistake for anyārtha. The only other occurrence of this stanza in the Eastern Cālukya corpus that I am aware of is in the Koṇḍakaṟipḻola grant of Viṣṇuvardhana III, where the variant of this word is anyasya.
RM emends the to gautamācāryyeṇa, which is probably correct, but I prefer not to interfere with names.

div.head: Plates
div.p: Greetings. The grandson of His Majesty King mahārāja Viṣṇuvardhana III or IV, the shelter of all the world sarva-lokāśraya whose pair of feet is illuminated by a nimbus of rays from the jewels that are his toenails, which have been rubbed smooth by the grindstones that are rubies at the tips of the crowns of the totality of kings bowed down by the prowess of the blade of his sword, whose clear reputation was enhanced by the ceaseless distribution of gold weighed on balance scales, That is, gold weighed on a scale against his body, the tulāpuruṣa mahādāna. and who was eager to adorn the lineage of the majestic Caḷukyas—who are of the Mānavya gotra which is praised by the entire world, who are sons of Hāriti, who attained kingship by the grace of Kauśikī’s boon, who are protected by the band of Mothers, who were deliberately appointed to kingship by Lord Mahāsena, to whom the realms of adversaries instantaneously submit at the mere sight of the superior Boar emblem they have acquired by the grace of the divine Nārāyaṇa, and whose bodies have been hallowed through washing in the purificatory ablutions avabhr̥tha of the Aśvamedha sacrifice—; the dear son of His Majesty King mahārāja Vijayāditya I or II, who repressed the onslaught of enemy armies para-cakra-vikrama by the sharp swordblade wielded by his own arm, whose pair of lotus feet were engilded by a mass of stamen dust i.e. pollen from the garlands on the brows of many peripheral rulers sāmanta , whose sins were washed off by the donation of gold weighed in many a balance scale and who was adorned by a host of irreproachable niravadya and noble virtues: namely His Majesty the Supreme Lord parameśvara of Emperors mahārājādhirāja and Sovereign bhaṭṭāraka Viṣṇuvardhana IV or V, shelter of all the world sarva-lokāśraya , upon hearing of whose ferocity the bravery of enemy kings para-narapati-vikrama instantly vanishes, who possesses the bodily marks of a universal sovereign cakravartin , who is the beloved of Royal Fortune lakṣmī as Viṣṇu the Wielder of the Śārṅga bow is the beloved of Lakṣmī, who is very profound by nature, like the ocean, who is a very Crocodile-bannered love god among men at whom women glance with flirtatious eyes made all the more appealing by a flurry of gestures delighting in ceaseless playful desire, who is a doomsday sun inasmuch as his rising dispels the dense darkness of enemies, who achieves hard-won victory viṣama-siddhi in battles thick with agitated clamour and the swaggering displays of great warriors, who is a cow of plenty kāmadhenu inasmuch as he grants the boons coveted by the destitute, the helpless, his friends, Brahmins dvija , his foremostThe word vr̥ndāraka, “ringleader,” does not seem to fit the context and may have been used by the composer wrongly instead of vr̥nda, “flock.” kinsmen, his allies and underlings bhr̥tya , and who defers toWhile I consistently translate the phrase (pāda+)anudhyāta, occurring in almost all Cālukya plates in the description of kings as “deliberately appointed by,” in this case it seems clear that the expression caraṇānudhyāta means that it is the king who pays respectful attention to the persons mentioned. the honoured presence pāda of gods, Brahmins and his elders guru —this Viṣṇuvardhana IV or V commands all householders kuṭumbin —including foremost the territorial overseers rāṣṭrakūṭa —who reside in Gudrahāra district viṣaya as follows.

Let it be known to you that on the occasion of an eclipse of the moon, for the augmentation of our vitality and health, we have given the village named Īṇḍubaḷḷi with an exemption from all taxes, the donation being sanctified by a libation of water, to Bhavvaśarman, a resident of belonging to the Kauśika gotra and the Taittirīya school, of the Aulupeya sūtra, whose great good reputation arises from his exposition of the purport of scriptural words and utterances,See the apparatus to line 24 for the textual problem here. who is engaged in the six duties of a Brahmin and follows the path of the Veda, the grandson of Viṣṇuśarman, a scholar of the Veda, Vedāṅga, Itihāsa and Purāṇa, and the son of Yajñaśarman, a scholar of all treatises śāstra .

Its boundaries are as follows. To the east, the boundary is Kalpaṭṭanabu. To the south, the boundary is Tāṟkaṭūru. To the west, the boundary is Niḍugāḍu. To the north, the boundary is Jakkanaceṟuvu. It is located in the midst of these four boundaries. Let no-one pose an obstacle to the enjoyment of rights over it. He who does so shall be conjoined with the five great sins. Vyāsa too has said:
Many kings have granted land, and many have preserved it as formerly granted. Whosoever at any time owns the land, the fruit reward accrued of granting it belongs to him at that time.
He who would seize land, whether given by himself or by another, shall be born as a worm in faeces for sixty thousand years.
There has never been and will never be a gift superior to the gift of land, nor has there ever been or will ever be a sin superior to the seizing of the same.
He who accepts granted land and he who offers land: both of these doers of meritorious deeds are guaranteed to dwell in heaven.

It is possible i.e. easy to give away what is yours, even if it is a great thing; but it is hard to preserve the property of another.I translate the emendation suggested in the apparatus to line 37, but not included in the body of the edition. When it comes to the question, “donation or preservation of previous grants?”—the answer is that preservation is superior to donation.

The executor ājñapti of this ruling dharma is the impeccable superintendent of justice dharma-saṁgraha I assume that dharma-saṁgraha is synonymous to dharmādhyakṣa or dharmādhikaraṇika, but it may be the title of a different official, or it may be used in a non-technical figurative sense as “storehouse of justice”. known as Eṟeyamma, who is valiant and fond of discipline.
Written likhita by Kautamācārya.The name may be a mistake for Gautamācārya.

The name of the donated village was read as Raṇḍubaḷḷi for the ARIE report, while RM asserts that it is correctly Reṇḍubaḷḷi. I in turn feel certain that the first character is Ī, and cannot be certain about some of the later characters (see the apparatus to line 26). I therefore prefer to assign a name based on the findspot rather than the granted village of uncertain name. Note that my reading of Īṇḍubaḷḷi is compatible with RM’s proposed identification with the (or a) modern village Eṇḍapalle; indeed, more so than Reṇḍubaḷḷi.
